# 159\n
{London, British Library, Add. 23986 verso of roll: Interludium de Clerico et Puella}\n
ca1300\n
482 402 E\n
{=NW Lincs=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The MS is a narrow roll of parchment with the dramatic verse interlude\n
written on one side of it. It finishes imperfectly. There is almost no\n
punctuation. The verses are broken up by the insertion of the relevant\n
speaker\'s name, sometimes boxed in ink lines, in the right hand\n
margin. In each case, an ink line runs between the lines of text to\n
the left margin to indicate precisely where the speaker changes=}\n
{=Script - early Anglicana with some influence from contemporary\n
documentary script=}\n
{=The first quarter of this side of the roll is blank except for modern\n
reference numbers and notes and some later medieval pen trials=} \n
{(*HIC *INCIPi^T *INTerLUDIUm DE CLerIcO & PUELLA(}\n
{\\}\n
{(*CLerICus AIT(}\n
{\\}\n
{>(*CLerICus(>}\n
{=ins, to right of text line=}\n

$rest/v-imp_RESTE\n
$well{w}/av{rh}_WEL\n

# 291\n
{London, British Library, Arundel 57, fols. 2r-4r; 13r-96v: Ayenbite of Inwyt, Pater Noster etc.}\n
C14a2\n
615 158 N\n
{=Canterbury, Kent=}\n
{=Sample tagged: fols. 2r-4r, 13r-32v, 79v-81v, 91r-96v=}\n
{=Script - according to Gradon (1979:7), quoting Malcolm Parkes: "the\n
script represents an idiosyncratic variant of the earlier engrossing\n
hand and marks a stage towards later Anglicana Formata"=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The Ayenbite of Inwyt is a translation of the Somme le Roi of 1280.\n
Most of the MS, fols. 13r-96v, is in the hand of Dan Michel, and was\n
written in 1340 at St Augustine\'s Canterbury - see, in Dan Michel\'s\n
own hand, the colophon on fol. 94r and the statement on fol. 2r. By\n
this date Dan Michel was an old man of 70 years or more, the language\n
may therefore be taken as representative of the late 13th rather than\n
the mid-14th. The first quire, fols 1-12, was added later and consists\n
of a copy of Aristotle\'s De Anima, see Pamela Gradon\'s notes - EETS OS\n
278, 1979 - to her reissue of Morris\'s 1866 edn - EETS OS 23. The\n
author`s preface and table of contents, are written by Dan Michel on\n
the bottoms of fols. 2r-4r of this first quire. Neither the Latin of\n
the Aristotle text, nor various prophecies, also in Latin and in a\n
later hand, are recorded here. After the Ayenbite proper follow in\n
English, also in DM\'s hand, Pater Noster, Ave Maria and Creed (fol. 94r);\n
Pseudo-Anselm De Custodia Interioris Hominis (fols. 94v-96v); and two\n
more versions of Ave Maria (fol. 96v). Dan Michel uses punctus, punctus\n
elevatus, virgule, colon, punctus interrogativus and paraph. These\n
are recorded as . .\' , : ? and para respectively. DM also uses a\n
marginal obelus to draw attention to points of interest. It is the\n
form of three dots in a triangle with a vertical line beneath=}\n
{=Original transcript provided by JJS, corrected, annotated and tagged\n
from microfilm by ML=}\n
{~f2r~}\n
{para}\n

$letter/npl<pr_LETTRES\n
{.\'}\n
!_*C:*C:\n
{=For the next four lines of text, the left hand part of the\n
page is taken up by the letters :*M^I:*C:*C: written very large.\n
Each colon represents three punctus one above the other in the MS.\n

{para}\n

$market/nOd_MARKAT\n
$make/vn<prK2_MAK+INDE $/vn<prK2_+INDE\n
{=Gradon (1979) makes no comment about this phrase and her glossary makes it\n
clear that she takes MAKINDE to be a present participle. This would\n
involve reading the prepositional phrase as parenthetical: "in them\n
who, making by market, leave their benefices". This reading is however\n
contradicted by her glossing of the term \'maki markat\' as "strike a\n
bargain". The BE "by" would then be redundant unless MAKINDE is taken\n
to be a verbal noun. See also MED s.v. market n. 3 (a)=}\n
{.\'}\n

$dihtan/vpp-pl_Y+DIST $ge-/xp-vpp_Y+\n
{=sic - Morris (1866) reads YDIFT and emends to YDIzT. Gradon (1979)\n
accepts Morris\'s reading and suggests YDIFT may be an early example of\n
the change from xt to ft, referring to Jordan paras 196 n. and 294.\n
But here DM definitely writes ST not FT. With ST the ascenders are\n
habitually ligatured as is the case here, whilst they are not so\n
joined in FT. The ST spelling here for xt must therefore represent\n
the 13th-century usage, more commonly seen in SWML texts, and\n
apparently adopted from Anglo-French=}\n
$as/RT_ASE\n

# 137\n
{London, British Library Arundel 248, fols. 154r-155r: 4 lyrics}\n

557 263 E\n
{=E Cambs=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - early Anglicana book hand=}\n
{=Note that the punctuation has not come out well on the reproduction\n
used. The writing, especially in the third lyric at the foot of f154r,\n
is very tiny and squashed and punctuation is even harder to make out\n
I have put in what I can see, but some may be missing that should be there=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{~f154r~}\n
{=lyric in 5 stanzas each written in 2 long lines beneath the Latin\n
version and the music=}\n

{=Further lyrics in French fill the rest of the folio=}\n

\n'
b'
\n
# 300\n
{London, British Library, Arundel 292, fol. 3r-v: Creed, Pater Noster, Ave Maria etc}\n
C13b2-C14a1\n
579 307 S\n
{=W Norfolk=}\n
{=Sample represents only a small part of the English in this hand.\n
See no. 150, The Bestiary for the English on fols. 4r-10v in the\n
same hand and similar but not identical language=}\n
{=Script - proto-Gothic book hand with typical C13 forking of\n
ascenders. It has some similarities to contemporary charter hand\n
(cf. e.g. Johnson and Jenkinson (1915 [1967], Plate 16). The form\n
of wynn made with three strokes and with an open top is unusual.\n
See Wright (1960 no. 8)=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=In the verses on fol. 3r-v, initial litterae notabiliores are\n
separated from the following text and rubricated. They are not\n
always formed as majuscules however and here, as in The Bestiary,\n
which is written as prose, I have not capitalised letters unless\n
they are given a capital form, whether or not they appear to have\n
rubrication. The scribe, both here and in The Bestiary, uses two\n
distinct types of <g> with distinct functions. Both have a single\n
lobe and a leftward curving tail as in a normal Caroline \'g\'. One has\n
an off stroke linking it with the following littera - this \'hooked\'\n
<g> stands for [g] and the rare occurrences of [d3]. The other lacks\n
the off stroke or \'hook\' and stands for all other functions of \'g\'.\n
See Wirtjes (1991: x) and the reference there to Gumbert and Vermeer\n
(1971). Gumbert and Vermeer refer to the hookless <g> as \'an unusual\n
yogh\' but its shape is nothing like yogh being identical to the\n
scribe\'s normal <g> but simply lacking the offstroke and here I\n
recognise this \'g\' as G2=}\n
{~f3r~}\n
{>}\n
{=ins, in top margin=}\n
!_*C.*X.\n
{>}\n
{>para (\'*CREDO IN DEUM\'(>}\n
{=ins in right hand margin=}\n
{>(\'*CREDO\'(>}\n
{=ins, repeated in the margin further to the right=}\n
$/P11N_*I\n

{(*MEMORARE NOUISSIMA TUA \\ & INETerNUM NOn PECCABIS.(}\n

\n'
b'
\n
# 150\n
{London, BL Arundel 292, fols. 4r-10v: the Bestiary}\n
C13b2-C14a1\n
579 307 S\n
{=W Norfolk=}\n
{=Sample represents most of the English in this hand. See no. 299 for the\n
English on fol. 3r-v in the same hand and similar but not identical language=}\n
{=Script - proto-Gothic book hand with typical C13 forking of ascenders.\n
It has some similarities to contemporary documentary hands (cf. e.g. Johnson and\n
Jenkinson (1915 [1967], Plate 16). The form of wynn made with three\n
strokes  and with an open top is unusual. See Wright (1960 no. 8)=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=Verse is written as prose. Punctuation mostly confined to a punctus at\n
the end of every verse line. The Latin titles are evidently in red.\n
Most of the letters at the beginning of verse lines appear from the\n
microfilm to have been rubricated to make them litterae notabiliores.\n
As with the verse texts on fol. 3r-v, I have only marked with an\n
asterisk those that have majuscule form. In many places the final text\n
has been written over an erasure. It is very difficult to tell from black and\n
white microfilm where all of these occur. I have noted any that are\n
clear and especially when the rewriting does not fit the space left.\n
For other notices of erasures see Hall (1920 no. XXI. The scribe, both\n
here and in the verses on fol. 3r-v, uses two distinct types of <g>\n
with distinct functions. Both have a single lobe and a leftward\n
curving tail as in a normal Caroline \'g\'. One has an off stroke\n
linking it with the following littera - this \'hooked\' <g> stands\n
for [g] and the rare occurrences of [d3]. The other lacks the off\n
stroke or \'hook\' and stands for all other functions of \'g\'. See\n
Wirtjes (1991: x) and the reference there to Gumbert and Vermeer\n
(1971). Gumbert and Vermeer refer to the hookless <g> as \'an unusual\n
yogh\' but its shape is nothing like yogh being identical to the\n
scribe\'s normal <g> but simply lacking the offstroke and here I\n
recognise this \'g\' as G2=}\n
{~f4r~}\n
{>(\'*NATurA LEOnIS J^A\'(>}\n

$mid{w}/pr_MID\n
{=Erasure of one letter before MID. Wirtjes (1991) reads MId while\n
acknowledging that it could be read as MID with an \'accent\' on I. She\n
says the scribe does not generally write accents but in fact he quite\n
frequently disambiguates I from other minims (as here) with an oblique\n
stroke. He does so in FINNES the next word, though there of course there\n
is no danger of ambiguity from the oblique stroke crossing a following D=}\n
$fin/npl<pr_FINN+ES $/pln<pr_+ES\n

{"fluctuating, unstable"}\n
$stead/n<pr_STEDE\n
{=This is taken by MED to refer to "turbulent seas" or perhaps to some\n
other danger like a sandbar. I wonder (see below) whether it could not\n
refer to a part of the sea  where the water moves in such a way as to\n
create a whirlpool and thus sucks objects into the vortex. It would\n
then be the story of the Sirens partially conflated with that of\n
Charybdis=} \n
{.}\n

$sink/vps23_SIN\\K+EN $/vps23_+EN\n
$mid{w}/pr_MIT+\n
$/T<pr-ad_+TE\n
$suck/n<pr_SUK\n
{=I.e. the whirlpool\'s sucking vortex, see OED s.v. suck sb. 1 sense\n
(6), MITTE being instrumental. The word SUK has caused multiple\n
editorial problems. MED, following Morris, and apparently taking\n
no note of OED, suggests that this should read SUIK and takes it\n
to be from OE swic, "trick". This is an unnecessary emendation and\n
in any case this scribal system does not elsewhere have U for [wi],\n
or even for [w], and the same word is in fact spelled SwIC elsewhere\n
in the text.  Hall assumes the word to refer to the sucking sound as\n
the ship goes under but this seems unnecessarily complicated. Another\n
possible (but I think less likely) reading but which would also\n
require no emendation is that the initial S is for OE sc-, normal in\n
this scribal system, and that the word represents OE scucca "devil" or\n
"monster", in  this case the siren who draws the ship down into the whirlpool=}\n
{.}\n
$/neg-v(>av)_NE\n

{\\}\n
$/P23G_HE\n
$breast/n<pr_BREST\n
$ofalr?/aj<pr_OUEL\n
{.}\n
{=this is unsatisfactory as it stands. The meaning seems to be\n
that wise man can sometimes escape the mermen "by means of"\n
or "with" (MID) something. Hall summarises the possibilities\n
in the notes to his edition, see also Wirtjes (1991). All ideas\n
require reading HE as "their" and editors emend to HE[RE]. Hall\n
says Maetzner suggests "with their heart incorruptible" equating\n
OUEL with OWScand. o\'falr I have tagged it this way because the\n
reading involves the least wrenching of possible meanings. The\n
other reading, apparently favoured by Morris who suggests OUEL\n
is "?evil" is something like "they have escaped from their evil\n
damage/danger". But OUEL for "evil" is an otherwise unknown\n
form and taking MID to mean "from" reverses its usual sense\n
and therefore seems an unlikely reading=}\n
$/P23N_HE\n

\n
# 277\n
{London, British Library, Cotton Caligula A.ix, part 1, hand A, fols. 3r-17rb (foot); 17va line 5-18vb line 6; 27ra lines 1-6 (BLIdE); 88ra-89rb line 3: Layamon A}\n
C13b1\n
381 271 N\n
{=N Worcs=}\n
{=Original transcript provided by JJS, corrected from microfilm by ML=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Script = Textura semi-quadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{~f3ra~}\n
{=I have tried to indicate capital letters as they appear in the MS which\n
are not necessarily the same as in the editions of Madden or of Brook\n
and Leslie (B&L). Unfortunately the rubrication used to indicate\n
capitals in the MS is not clear on black and white microfilm and\n
I have tended to rely more on majuscule shape to assign the * indicating\n
capitalisation and do not mention colour. There is bound to be some\n
inconsistency, however, in the final result. The line-breaks are those\n
of the MS which is not written in verse lines but as prose in two\n
columns. Rhyme is irregular and when it does occur is so often mixed\n
with assonance or half-rhyme that I have made no attempt to mark it\n
except where there is a clear (pure-rhyme) rhyming couplet marking the\n
end of a section of the story or sense unit. Note that in the\n
abbreviation for "that" - barred thorn - the bar touches the ascender of\n
thorn but does not bisect it. This figura does not seem to be used,\n
however, for an abbreviation for "there" and I have therefore realised\n
it as y~ not as yer. Contrast the hand of part 2 of this MS - Owl and\n
Nightingale - where the same figura, with the hook not touching the\n
ascender, is used for "that" and "there" and both have therefore been\n
realised as yer. Cf. also hand B of Layamon A similar to this. In fact\n
the main differences between hand A and hand B of Layamon are in the\n
generally greater regularity of hand A. It has both double and single\n
compartment A but seems never to have single compartment A with hooked\n
second element as is common in hand B. Hand B, however, is variable to\n
such an extent that most of hand A\'s characteristics are present in\n
his hand which makes separation of the stints a bit problematic=}\n
{>)*ROBERTUS *COTTON *BRUCE)>}\n
{=ins, in top margin in a modern hand=}\n
{(INCIPIT \'HYSTORIA BRUTONUM\'(}\n
{\\}\n
$/AN_*A*N\n
{=Five-line, decorated initial *A with further decoration in the top,\n
left-hand and bottom margins=} \n

$writ/n_WRIH\n
{=Originally WRIH and a stroke has been added to the ascender of H as if\n
to change it to a very tall T to make WRIT. But no attempt has been\n
made to erase the lobe of H. Madden and B&L both read WRIHT without\n
comment but one must read either WRIH (the original) or WRIT\n
(the correction)=}\n

$/P13GMpl_HIS\n
{\\}\n
$loth/ajpl_LAd+E $/plaj_+E\n
$fiend/npl_F[E]OnD $/pln_0\n
{=MS reading looks like FEOOnD - so reads Madden - but originally the\n
scribe wrote FREOnD, realised his mistake and overwrote the R with an\n
E failing to erase the original E which Madden has taken for O. Very\n
often the scribe\'s EO has an element of biting and resembles OO because\n
the lack of the usual space between the two letters gives a right side\n
closure to the E and if the hairstroke forming its lobe is missing or\n
faded the illusion is complete. There are several other examples however\n
and I believe EO is intended in each case=}\n
{.}\n
$/P13GM_*HIS\n

{.\'}\n
{=Both Madden and B&L read QUARCERNE but Madden corrects the reading\n
to QUARTERNE in his errata. The head stroke of this scribe\'s C normally\n
points diagonally down and is not horizontal like this littera. It is\n
true that most of the scribe\'s Ts have a head stroke beinning to the\n
left of the upright, but not all do, especially after Carlingian\n
minuscule R where the head stroke would foul the shoulder of the R.\n
Words with RT for comparison are surprisingly rare apart from HEORTE\n
where the R is invariably 2-shaped after O. But cf. aeRT fol. 6va\n
line 3=}\n

$wretch/npl<pr_WRECCH+AN $/pln<pr_+AN\n
{=Second C corrected from S. The hairline joining the limb of the H\n
to the ascenderhas not come out clearly suggesting that it perhaps began\n
as L, while the biting of following A to the limb of H makes the word\n
superficially look like WRECSLUN. But the reading WRECCHAN is correct=}\n

{=Corrupt text? Otho paraphrases yAT HIM yE EyERE WERE. Could yE be\n
for Ye:on "thrive" either as a subjunctive: "that to him it might\n
thrive", or with MOT having dropped out as an infinitive? Cf line 10522\n

either indicative or subjunctive, but formally yE seems OK for subjunctive sg.\n

$wigel/npl<pr_WIzELED+EN $/pln<pr_+EN\n
{=sic - this is a supposed error for WIzELEN "wiles, tricks" (so Madden,\n
and MED. It does seem the simplest interpretation and is semantically\n
plausible. Otho does not have this line so is no help. I find the\n
addition of ED to the word an implausible scribal error, whatever the\n
poet may originally have intended. The word has the shape of a compound\n
noun and it is tempting to read it as a reflex of OE wi:gle:oY - "battle\n
song" or "war cry". Formally, however this is difficult, because in this\n
scribe\'s language reflexes of OE [e:o] are always spelled EO not E while\n
elsewhere he has WI-EAX and WIaeX "battle-axe" with no sign of yogh=}\n
$mid{w}/pr_MID\n
$wrench/npl<pr_WRENCH+EN $/pln<pr_+EN\n

$handfast/n<pr_HOND-FaeST $fast/ajn<pr-k_-FaeST\n
{="betrothal". MED takes this to be the past participle of the verb\n
hondfesten with i- prefix from OE ge-. But it is not plausible that the\n
past participle prefix would attach to the nominal element. One would\n
expect rather hond-i-faest. So I take this to be an early example of the\n
noun for which see OED s.v. handfast, n. II. 4.=}\n
{.\'}\n
